statement.tex: \text{Find the integral of the function}\\ \sin x \cdot \sin 2 x \cdot \sin 3 x \,

step.context: \text{The following substitution would convert}\\ f(x) = \sin x \cdot \sin 2 x \cdot \sin 3 x \text{ to the more easily}\\ \text{integrable form } \sin \theta_1 + \sin \theta_2 + \sin \theta_3 \\ \text{or } \sum_{i=1}^{i=n} \cos \theta_i
step.tex: \text{Using trigonometric identities,}\\ \sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}\left[ cos(A-B) - cos(A+B) \right] \text{ and } \\ \sin A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}\left[ \sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B) \right]
\text{Using trigonometric identities,}\\ \sin^2 x + \cos^2 x = 1 \\ \cos 2x = 2 \cos^2 x - 1 = 1 - 2 \sin^2 x \\
step.reason:
f(x) = \dfrac{1}{4} [ \sin 2 x + \sin 0 - \sin 6x +sin 4x] \\
\therefore \int \sin x \cdot \sin 2 x \cdot \sin 3 x \, dx \\ \qquad \qquad = \int \dfrac{1}{4} [ \sin 2 x - \sin 6x +sin 4x] dx
